values.alignmentText: Mountainous terrain and well-kept parks offer plentiful outdoor escapes despite dense cities.
Heatwaves and rising seas threaten coastal zones though mitigation planning is active.
Four distinct seasons bring humid summers and cold winters, challenging our mild-climate preference.
Frequent fine-dust episodes from industry and China degrade urban air.
Typhoons and occasional quakes occur but building standards reduce impact.
10–20°C (50–68°F) with yellow dust and cherry blossoms.
22–30°C (72–86°F) and humid monsoon rains.
10–22°C (50–72°F) dry and clear.
-2–5°C (28–41°F) with occasional snow.
Busan and Jeju offer beaches but not year-round swimming.
Summer waters near 24°C (75°F) cool by fall.
National parks, islands, and seasonal blossoms are scenic.
2024 rate about ₩9,860/hour (~$7.50) provides modest baseline.
Seoul devs earn roughly $45k–$70k USD, lower than US but livable.
Enterprise and game studios use .NET but market is smaller than Java.
Ruby is niche with limited openings outside startups.
E‑7 and other work visas exist yet require sponsorship and degree.
Advanced high-income economy with strong exports and tech sector.
Pandemic normalized some remote work but office presence remains standard.
Long hours culture clashes with our family’s balance goals despite reforms.
Legal 40 but overtime often pushes weeks toward 50–60.
15 days after first year by labor law.
Workers often take fewer than allowed due to culture.
Seoul’s pace is fast and competitive; smaller cities slower.
Parents often return after 7 pm; kids attend after-school hagwons.
Family outings to parks, cafes, or hiking; catch up on rest.
Strong family emphasis but work hours limit together time.
Non-monogamy has little social or legal acceptance.
High academic expectations and structured extracurriculars.
Safe with many kid cafes and parks yet space is limited.
Public schools high-performing but intense; international schools costly.
Government expanding daycare though spots in Seoul fill quickly.
Monthly subsidies and free preschool for ages 3–5.
Foreign residents can access some subsidies but coverage varies.
Universal and high quality with strong outcomes.
Public schools open to foreigners though Korean fluency is expected.
Heavy reliance on hagwons adds cost and pressure.
Parental leave and child allowances exist but uptake low for fathers.
Some benefits extend to residents yet bureaucracy can limit use.
Top universities like Seoul National offer world-class programs.
Many universities have English tracks and scholarships for internationals.
Traditional expectations persist though younger generations push change.
Nonbinary identities receive limited recognition outside activist circles.
Legal equality but wage gap and glass ceiling remain issues.
Strong beauty culture and modesty expectations.
Professional success and military service shape male roles.
Blend of cutting-edge tech, pop culture, and ancient heritage.
English taught widely; proficiency moderate outside tourist areas.
Democratic politics with active civil society yet conservative social views linger.
Cold War legacy fosters skepticism toward Marxism.
About half the population identifies with no religion.
Public discourse is modest; sex education improving slowly.
Activism growing but legal recognition and social acceptance remain limited.
Tight-knit circles form around schools and workplaces; integration takes effort.
Strong national pride tied to rapid development and cultural exports.
Historical tensions with Japan and North Korea; pragmatic with China.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Respected for economic success yet viewed through security lens.
Seoul’s nightlife is vibrant with late-night dining and entertainment.
Streetwear and grooming-focused styles set regional trends.
K-fashion blends modesty with cutting-edge looks.
Hiking, gaming, and cafe socializing are popular.
Board-game cafes and PC bangs support a growing tabletop scene.
K-pop concerts and clubs provide abundant music venues.
Expat and tech meetups occur regularly in Seoul.
Mountains and rivers are reachable even from major cities.
Presidential republic with regular competitive elections.
Religious groups exert limited direct influence on policy.
Labor laws exist but enforcement against overwork is weak.
Liberal democracy paired with strong anti-communist stance.
Institutions are stable though past military rule prompts vigilance.
Market economy dominated by chaebols yet entrepreneurial scene growing.
Domestic stability high but North Korea remains a security concern.
Media is largely free though national security messages are common.
Emphasis on anti-North sentiment and national unity.
Gradual expansion of welfare and child incentives.
Varies with scandals; moderate overall.
Chaebol-political ties continue to raise concerns.
Influence peddling and favoritism linked to conglomerates.
Seoul housing costly with heavy reliance on jeonse deposits.
Violent crime rates are low and streets feel safe.
Universal National Health Insurance offers affordable care.
Foreign residents can enroll after registration and pay into the system.
Government subsidies help with daycare but long waits in cities.
Support improving yet not as generous as Nordic models.
Students excel in OECD rankings but pressure and rote learning are concerns.
Subways and buses are extensive, punctual, and affordable.
Advanced mixed economy with strong export base.
Income tax withheld monthly with annual reconciliation.
Middle-income families face roughly 10–20% effective rates.
Highly digitized banking; mobile payments ubiquitous.
Seoul living costs are high relative to local wages.
National Pension Service provides modest old-age benefits.
Foreign workers contribute and may reclaim pension when leaving.
Multiple work and business visas exist but paperwork is detailed.
Generally neutral reception; cultural adaptation expected.
E and D visas typically valid 1–3 years before renewal.
Requires 5+ years residency, language test, and renouncing prior citizenship.
Spouses and children can accompany on dependent visas.
Processing takes several months with moderate legal fees.
Strict immigration checks; overstays result in fines or bans.
Generally not allowed except in rare talent or marriage cases.
Must maintain employment and address changes; bureaucracy in Korean.
Large online and mobile game sector offers many roles.
Home to Nexon, NCSoft, Netmarble, and others.
Indie meetups and university clubs support collaboration.
Government incubators and esports culture aid startups, though competition is stiff.
World-class broadband, transit, and smart-city tech everywhere.
